title: Overall
stimulusHtml:
9 - 8 - 7 - 6 points: STRONGER

ESSAYS WILL DEMONSTRATE THE FOLLOWING QUALITIES WITH VARYING DEGREES OF EFFECTIVENESS.

  1. Has a clear, well-developed thesis. Makes a clear distinction between Luther and Calvin (e.g. time-frame, locale). Posits views of each on both political authority and social order.

  2. Is well organized. Compares and contrasts using each reformer on each topic (political authority and social order, although may focus more on political authority, blurring the two).

  3. Addresses the terms of the question — task(s), content, chronology — perhaps with some unevenness. Is clear on the identity of each reformer and his time period. If theological points are raised, they are shown to tie to political authority and/or social order. Understands "political authority" as secular power (town/city magistrates, prince, king, nobil­ity, aristocracy). Social order is understood as maintaining order in society.

  4. Supports thesis with specific evidence. Citation of texts from each reformer is not mandatory. Attribution of viewpoints, principles, activi­ties in comparison/contrast format, is.

  5. May contain minor errors; even a 9 need not be flawless. Luther active after Calvin is not minor.

5 - 4 points: MIXED

THESE SCORES SHOULD BE ASSIGNED JUDICIOUSLY.

  1. Contains a thesis, though perhaps superficial or simplistic. States the obvious: "Luther and Calvin had some of the same and some different views on political authority and social order." (Doesn't elaborate with evidence on this.)

  2. Responds to the terms of the question unevenly; task(s), evidence, chronology. Is overwhelmingly weighted toward the views of only one reformer, e.g., doesn't offer clear comparisons/contrasts between Luther and Calvin.

  3. May contain errors, factual and/or interpretive.

3 - 2 - 1 - 0 points: WEAKER

ESSAYS WILL DEMONSTRATE THE FOLLOWING QUALITIES WITH VARYING DEGREES OF EFFECTIVENESS. ESSAYS SCORED 0 OR 1 MAY ATTEMPT TO ADDRESS THE QUESTION BUT FAIL TO DO SO.

  1. Thesis confused, unfocused,or absent, or simply restates question. E.g.: "Luther and Calvin can be compared and contrasted on their views toward political authority and social order." (No development of this.)

  2. Misconstrues the question, or omits major tasks. Treats matter of theol­ogy and/or liturgy without, or with superficial reference to either politi­cal authority or social order. May address only one of the tasks: Luther, Calvin, political authority, social order.

  3. Supporting information superficial, irrelevant, or missing. Evidence so general as not to pertain to either Luther or Calvin. Simple categorical statements with no evidence attributable to either Luther or Calvin. Discusses theology of Luther or Calvin with no connection to the topic of political authority.

  4. May contain major errors. Chronology of Luther/Calvin/Reformation era. Identity of Luther/Calvin.

-- NON-RESPONSIVE
Response totally off-task, absent, or irrelevant.
